translated: Sutra of King Notri's Ten Dreams

King Notri dreamed of ten things while lying in bed at night.
What were the ten things?
First, he dreamed of three vases placed together, with the vases on both sides full, their qi coming and going, but not entering the empty vase in the middle.
Second, he dreamed of a horse eating with its mouth and also eating with its hindquarters.
Third, he dreamed of a small tree sprouting flowers.
Fourth, he dreamed of a small tree bearing fruit.
Fifth, he dreamed of a person seeking rope, with a sheep following behind, the sheep's owner eating the rope.
Sixth, he dreamed of a fox sitting on a golden bed, eating from a golden vessel.
Seventh, he dreamed of a large ox returning to drink milk from its calf.
Eighth, he dreamed of four bulls from the four directions mooing and coming to fight each other, about to clash but not knowing where the bulls were.
Ninth, he dreamed of a large pond, with the center muddy and the four sides clear.
Tenth, he dreamed of a large stream with the water flowing straight red.
After the king had these dreams, he woke up and was greatly afraid of losing his country, his body, and his wife and children.
The next day, the king summoned his ministers and officials, as well as the monks who understood dreams, and asked:
Last night I lay down and dreamed of these ten things. After the dream, I woke up and was terrified. I am unhappy in my mind. Who can interpret the dream?
Among the monks, there was a brahmin who said:
I can interpret the king's dream for him, but I'm afraid the king will be sorrowful and unhappy upon hearing it.
The king said:
Speak as you see fit. Do not hold anything back.
The brahmin said:

Your Majesty's dreams are all inauspicious, each a bad omen. You should take your most beloved concubines, princes, and close attendants, and kill them all to make offerings to the heavens. Then Your Majesty may be spared.
Your Majesty's bedding and the precious treasures on your body should all be burned as offerings to the heavens. In this way, Your Majesty's body may be spared.
When the king heard the brÄhmaá¹‡a's interpretation of the dreams like this, he became greatly distressed and unhappy, and returned to the fasting chamber to ponder this matter.
The king had a principal consort named Maá¹‡i, who came to the king and asked him:
Why have you entered the fasting chamber, distressed and unhappy? Have I committed any offense against you?
The king said:
You have committed no offense against me, I am just distressed myself.
The consort asked again:
What is it that causes Your Majesty to be distressed?
The king said:
Do not ask me about this. If you hear it, it will make you unhappy.
The queen said again:
I am half of the king's body. If there is good or evil, the king should tell me. Why do you not tell each other?
The king then told the queen:
Last night I dreamed of ten things. After dreaming, I woke up and was greatly worried and afraid, fearing that my country, body, wife, and children would be lost.
I summoned the ministers, officials, and monks to tell them the ten things I dreamed of. A brahmin explained my dream, saying:

'You should take your most beloved queen, prince, and close attendants, slaves, and white elephants and famous horses, and kill them all to offer to the heavens, and burn the bedding, clothing, and precious treasures you wear, and only then will the king be able to avoid disaster.'
This is why I am worried and unhappy.
The queen said:
The king should not worry!

It is like a person buying gold, polishing it on a stone. The good and bad colors are seen on the stone. Now the Buddha is nearby in the monastery, not far from the country. Why not go ask about the dream meaning?
If the Buddha understands, follow it.

The king then ordered his attendants and ministers to prepare the carriage and set out. He reached the Buddha's place and walked slowly. The king got off the carriage and went to the Buddha's place. He touched his head to the Buddha's feet, sat back, and said to the Buddha:
I had ten dreams last night:
First, I dreamed of three vases placed together. The vases on both sides were full, and the qi flowed back and forth, not entering the empty vase in the middle.
Second, I dreamed of a horse eating with its mouth and also eating with its rump.
Third, I dreamed of a small tree growing flowers.
Fourth, I dreamed of a small tree growing fruit.ğŸ”½Fifth, I dreamed of a person asking for rope, and behind the person was a sheep, the sheep's owner eating the rope.
Sixth, I dreamed of a fox sitting on a golden bed, eating from a golden vessel.
Seventh, dreaming of a large ox suckling from its calf.
Eighth, dreaming of four oxen mooing and coming from the four directions, about to fight, but not knowing where the oxen are when they are about to join or not join.
Ninth, dreaming of a large pond, with the center muddy and the four sides clear.
Tenth, dreaming of a stream flowing straight red.
I had these dreams and woke up terrified, fearing for the loss of my country, my body, my wife and children. Only the Buddha can explain the ten things I dreamed of. I wish to hear your teachings.
The Buddha said:
Your Majesty, do not worry!
Your Majesty's dreams are all without consequence. Your Majesty's dreams are about future events in the world to come, not the present.
The Buddha said:

In the future, people will not fear the law and prohibitions, will be licentious and greedy for profit, will be jealous and insatiable, will have little righteousness and principle, will be without a compassionate mind, and will be happy and angry without a sense of shame.
The Buddha said:

First, the dream of three jars side by side, with the jars on both sides full, their vapors coming and going, not entering the empty jar in the middle, means that in the future, the wealthy will follow each other and not look at the poor. The king's dream of three jars side by side is exactly this.
The king should not be afraid, should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king, the prince, or the queen.
The Buddha said:

Second, the king's dream of a horse eating with its mouth and also eating with its hindquarters means that in the future, emperors and great ministers, having received their official salaries from the state granaries, will still exploit the myriad people, not knowing when to be content. The king's dream of a horse eating with its mouth and also eating with its hindquarters is exactly this.
The king should not be afraid, should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king, the prince, or the queen.ğŸ”½The Buddha said:

Third, the dream of a small tree sprouting flowers means that in future generations, people will have white hair on their heads before they are thirty years old. Greedy for sex and desire, young people will be strong but old. The king's dream of a small tree sprouting flowers is precisely this.
The king should not be afraid, should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king's country, to the prince, or to the queen.
The Buddha said:

Fourth, the king's dream of a small tree bearing fruit means that in future generations, women will get married before they are fifteen years old, and return home with a baby in their arms, not knowing shame or conscience. The king's dream of a small tree bearing fruit is precisely this.
The king should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king's country, to the prince, or to the queen.

The Buddha said:ğŸ”½Fifth, the king's dream of a large tree bearing fruit means that in future generations, people will be stingy and greedy, not giving to their parents, wives, children, or servants. The king's dream of a large tree bearing fruit is precisely this.

Fifth, the dream of a person asking for rope, with a sheep following behind, and the sheep's owner eating the rope, means that in future generations, husbands will go out on business trips, leaving their wives behind, and they will then have sexual relations with other men and consume their wealth. The king's dream of a person asking for rope is precisely this.
The king should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king, the prince, or the queen.
The Buddha said:

Sixth, the king's dream of a fox sitting on a golden bed and eating from a golden vessel means that in future generations, lowly people will become honorable and wealthy, and be respected by the masses, while the descendants of dukes and marquises will become poor and lowly, sitting in lower positions and eating last. The king's dream of a fox sitting on a golden bed and eating from a golden vessel is precisely this.
The king should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king, the prince, or the queen.
The Buddha said:

Seventh, the king's dream of a large ox sucking milk from a calf means that in future generations people will lack propriety and righteousness. Mothers will act as matchmakers for their daughters, enticing men from other families to have relations with their daughters. They will sell their daughters to obtain wealth to support themselves, and will not know shame. The king's dream of a large ox sucking milk from a calf is precisely this.
The king should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king, the prince, or the queen.
The Buddha said:

The eighth dream, of four bulls from the four directions mooing and coming to fight, about to join but not knowing where the bulls are, means that in the future, emperors, officials, and the people will all lack a sincere heart, will deceive each other, be foolish and angry, and will not respect Heaven and Earth. For this reason, rain and moisture will not come in time. When officials and the people pray for rain, Heaven will cause clouds to rise from the four directions with thunder and lightning. The officials and people will all say it will rain, but in an instant the clouds will disperse and the rain will not fall.
Why is this?
Because the emperors, officials, and people lack loyalty, righteousness, and kindness.
The king's dream of four bulls mooing and coming to fight, about to join but not knowing where the bulls are, is precisely this.
The king should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king, the prince, or the queen.
The Buddha said:

The ninth dream of the king seeing a large pond with muddy water in the middle and clear water on the four sides means that in the later world, the central countries will be in turmoil and the governance will be uneven, with the people being unfilial to their parents and disrespectful to the elders, while the border countries will be peaceful and clear, with the people harmonious, friendly, and filial to both parents. The king's dream of a large pond with muddy water in the middle and clear water on the four sides is exactly this.
The king should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king, the prince, or the queen.
The Buddha said:

The tenth dream of the king seeing a large stream flowing with pure red water means that in the later world, the various countries will be in conflict, raising armies and gathering troops to attack each other, forming chariots, infantry, cavalry, and engaging in battle, killing each other in countless ways, with blood flowing like a stream of pure red on the roads. The king's dream of a large stream flowing with pure red water is exactly this.
The king should not be afraid!
There will be no harm to the king, the prince, or the queen.
The Buddha said:
The dreams the king had are all about future events in the world to come, not about present affairs. The king should not be afraid or worried.
The king immediately knelt for a long time and said:

Having received the Buddha's teaching, my mind is overjoyed, just like a person holding a small vessel filled with ghee. The ghee is much and the vessel is small, so they seek a larger vessel to contain it, and are at ease without further fear. Now, I have received the Buddha's grace and have attained peace.
The king then bowed to the Buddha and returned to the palace, where he bestowed honors on the principal wife, and all the ministers' salaries were reduced.
The king said:
From now on I will not believe the words of the various non-Buddhist practitioners and Brahmins.
The Sutra of King Ajatashatru's Ten Dreams
